snippet: It is possible that the Dreamliner’s batteries were overcharged, but to lift a grounding order, Boeing must demonstrate that it can prevent similar episodes from happening.
abstract: Boeing is scrambling to devise technical fix that would allow its 787 Dreamliners to fly again soon, after Federal Aviation Administration grounded technologically advanced aircraft worldwide; investigators in United States and Japan are trying to figure out what caused plane's lithium-ion batteries to overheat.

byline.original: By JAD MOUAWAD and MATTHEW L. WALD
byline.contributor: Nicola Clark and Christopher Drew contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: It is possible that the Dreamliner’s batteries were overcharged, but to lift a grounding order, Boeing must demonstrate that it can prevent similar episodes from happening.

headline.seo: Boeing Closer to Answer on 787s, but Not to Getting Them Back in Air
headline.main: Boeing Closer to an Answer, but Not to Getting 787s Back in the Air
headline.print_headline: Boeing Closer to an Answer, but Not to Getting 787s Back in the Air
